Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology for FY 2011
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2011, Intersections of Biology and Mathematical and Physical Sciences. The fellowship supports a research and training plan in a host laboratory for the Fellow whose plan involves innovation at the intersection of biology with physics and applied mathematics. The research and training plan for this fellowship to Fulton Rockwell is entitled, "Is water lost from plant leaves as a liquid or a vapor?? The host institutions for this research are Cornell University and University of Chicago; and the sponsoring scientists are Drs. Abraham Stroock and Charles Kevin Boyce.

A fundamental gap in our understanding of leaf structure and function is whether transpiration follows a predominantly vapor or liquid path between the leaf veins and the `valves' on the leaf surface, the stomata. Answering this question will inform not only our understanding of leaf function, but also stomatal regulation of transpiration and the contributions of leaf structure to instantaneous water use efficiency, that is, carbon gained per water molecule transpired. The dominant mode of transport inside transpiring leaves remains an open question precisely because it occurs at the intersection of biology, chemical thermodynamics and transport phenomena. To address the question of competition between liquid and vapor, a combination of modeling and experimental determination of the internal geometry and material properties of leaves is being employed.

Training in coupled heat and mass transport is provided by the Stroock lab at Cornell University, whose members combine expertise in chemical engineering and microfluidics with an interest in bio-mimetic design. Expertise in obtaining structural information from analysis of micro-CT scans of leaves comes from training in the Boyce lab, at the University of Chicago, which seeks to reconstruct the physiology of fossil plants based on structure-function relations observed in extant lineages. Broader impacts include developing educational materials appropriate to both adults and school groups on the life of trees that incorporate a perspective on plants informed by the research results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project resulted in new insights into the process of "transpiration," or the loss of water from the interior of a leaf to the surrounding dry air that occurs during photosynthesis, the process by which plants turn carbon dioxide into sugars and the other carbon-based compounds that provide us with food, fiber, and fuel. The loss of water that accompanies photosynthesis is important as plants must avoid dehydration to survive and grow, and thus the necessity of maintaining hydration constrains how much they can open their stomata, the pores that regulate carbon dioxide uptake by leaves. Understanding how leaf structure and material properties influence transpiration is therefore critical for improving the water-use efficiency by which plants produce socially desirable commodities.

With respect to intellectual merit, the work reported on here developed the first model for water transport inside leaves that accounts rigorously for both liquid water and water vapor transport, greatly improving our understanding of both where water evaporates inside leaves, and how it reaches the stomata. This understanding can in future be incorporated into models of stomatal responses to the environment of the plant, as well as plant water use efficiency (water lost per carbon gained), to understand the characteristics plant breeders and molecular biologists may target to improve the efficiency of agronomic plant water use. With respect to broader impacts on society, the funded work addresses a fundamental aspect of the problem of delivering the food, fuel, and fiber we require from plants with a minimum of water, which is of high importance to society.

An important insight into leaf function dervied from this work is that leaves can exploit temperature driven vapor transport of water through their internal air spaces to deliver water to the stomata and so satisfy transpirational water loss. This allows the 'soft' (low structural carbohydrate investment) leaves of herbaceous plants to support high transpiration and carbon uptake rates, without requiring them to invest in 'stiff' (high structural carbohydrate investment) tissues required to enable large liquid flows of water to the stomata. Such a strategy could improve the efficiency of photosynthesis in terms of grain yield in that it requires lower structural investment over the life of a leaf. 

The funding provided for this project also supported interdisciplinary communication between the fields of chemical engineering and plant water relations, in the form of a review paper exploring the physical bases of current controversies in the latter field. Plant water relations can be viewed as a specialized application of chemcial engineering principles to biology, but most plant water relations scientists have stronger biological than physical science backgrounds. Sub-fields such as plant water relations, though treating subjects of fundamental importance to society such as plant productivity, tend to also be smaller and therefore cross-discipline collaboration and communication is essential to maintain the intellectual health and scientific rigor of the discipline. The aforementioned review appears in a special issue of the leading plant physiology journal and should help to avoid misallocation of scientific (and so societal)  resources.
